definitions: The maximal ability to take in, transport, and utilize oxygen during exercise.
The upper limit of the body’s oxygen delivery and use during sustained activity.
A measure of how much oxygen the cardiovascular and muscular systems can process.
The ceiling of aerobic energy supply capability.
The physiological limit of oxygen uptake and utilization.
The capacity of the heart, lungs, blood, and muscles to support aerobic metabolism.
A determinant of endurance performance reflecting oxygen transport efficiency.
The maximal integrated function of respiratory, cardiovascular, and muscular systems.
The highest rate at which aerobic energy can be produced.
The maximal rate of oxygen consumption during exercise.
The peak speed of aerobic ATP production.
The intensity at which aerobic metabolism reaches its maximum output.
A measure of aerobic system output rather than duration.
The maximum oxygen flux through the aerobic system.
The rate-based expression of aerobic fitness.
The point at which increases in workload no longer increase oxygen uptake.
The ability to rapidly change direction while maintaining balance and control.
A combination of speed, coordination, and neuromuscular control during direction changes.
Rapid whole-body movement with changes in velocity or direction in response to stimuli.
The capacity to decelerate, reorient, and accelerate efficiently.
Change-of-direction ability integrated with perceptual and decision-making elements.
A movement skill requiring strength, balance, and motor control.
Multidirectional speed under control.
The ability to reposition the body efficiently in space.
The ability to sustain high-intensity effort via anaerobic pathways.
The total amount of work that can be performed anaerobically.
Energy-producing capacity of glycolytic and phosphagen systems combined.
Tolerance for repeated or sustained high-intensity exercise.
The volume-based component of anaerobic performance.
The ability to maintain output during short-duration intense exercise.
Anaerobic work potential rather than peak output.
The endurance of non-oxidative energy systems.
The highest rate of anaerobic energy production.
Peak power output generated without oxygen.
The rate-based performance of phosphagen and glycolytic systems.
Explosive energy production over very short durations.
Maximum non-oxidative ATP generation rate.
Short-duration maximal effort capability.
Anaerobic system speed rather than endurance.
Peak output of non-aerobic metabolism.
The measurement of human body size, shape, and proportions.
Quantification of physical dimensions such as height, mass, and limb lengths.
Body measurement used in performance and health assessment.
Structural assessment of body characteristics.
Physical measurement techniques used in sport science.
Assessment of body dimensions for classification or tracking.
Measurement of external body characteristics.
A foundational method for evaluating growth, development, and physique.
Sport-specific execution capacity influenced by multiple factors.
The outcome of physical, technical, tactical, and psychological abilities.
The observable expression of training adaptations in sport.
Competitive execution effectiveness.
Integrated expression of fitness and skill.
How well an athlete performs in their sport context.
Performance shaped by preparation, skill, and decision-making.
The realized output of an athlete’s abilities.
A summary of test results across performance domains.
A multidimensional snapshot of an athlete’s strengths and weaknesses.
A compiled representation of physical performance qualities.
Performance benchmarking across key fitness variables.
An assessment framework guiding individualized training.
A diagnostic overview of athlete capabilities.
A performance fingerprint used for planning.
A consolidated athlete assessment report.
The ability to maintain center of mass over base of support.
Postural control in static or dynamic conditions.
Neuromuscular control of body position.
Stability during stillness or movement.
Control of equilibrium.
The capacity to resist perturbations.
Coordination of sensory and motor systems for posture.
Maintenance of body alignment under gravity.
The relative proportions of fat mass and fat-free mass.
Distribution of body tissues.
The makeup of the body by tissue type.
The ratio of adipose to lean tissue.
A structural characteristic influencing performance and health.
Assessment of fat, muscle, bone, and water components.
Physique composition rather than size alone.
The partitioning of total body mass.
A statistical measure representing the center of a dataset.
Typical value around which data cluster.
Summary statistic describing average performance.
Mean, median, or mode of a distribution.
Indicator of dataset central location.
A representative value of a dataset.
Statistical descriptor of typical outcome.
Measure summarizing where data are centered.
Statistics used to summarize and describe datasets.
Methods that organize and present data meaningfully.
Tools such as mean, SD, and range.
Non-inferential data summaries.
Techniques that describe what the data show.
Numerical summaries of performance data.
Data reduction methods for interpretation.
Statistics focused on description rather than inference.
The change between two measurements for the same subject.
Posttest minus pretest value.
Individual change over time.
Raw performance change metric.
Within-subject performance difference.
Unadjusted measure of improvement or decline.
Simple delta between two scores.
Absolute change calculation.
A standardized measure of the magnitude of a difference.
Quantifies practical importance of change.
Size of an effect independent of sample size.
Magnitude of relationship or intervention impact.
Standardized change metric (e.g., Cohen’s d).
Indicator of meaningfulness beyond p-values.
Scale-free measure of effect strength.
Practical significance indicator.
The range of motion available at a joint.
Joint mobility capability.
Extent of movement allowed by tissues.
Capacity to move through full ROM.
Passive or active joint movement range.
Mobility at one or more joints.
Soft tissue extensibility.
Joint movement freedom.
Statistics used to draw conclusions about a population from a sample.
Methods for hypothesis testing and estimation.
Analytical tools that go beyond description.
Statistical inference about broader populations.
Probability-based conclusions.
Generalization from sample data.
Statistics involving confidence and uncertainty.
Decision-making statistics.
The arithmetic average of a dataset.
Sum of values divided by number of observations.
Central tendency sensitive to outliers.
Most common summary statistic.
Numerical average value.
Balance point of a dataset.
Average performance score.
Expected value under symmetry.
A measure of dispersion around the mean.
Typical distance of values from the average.
Variability indicator in a dataset.
Spread of data points.
Consistency measure of performance.
Statistical dispersion metric.
Extent of score variability.
Measure of distribution width.
The degree to which values differ within a dataset.
Spread or inconsistency of measurements.
Fluctuation in repeated measures.
Performance dispersion.
Natural variation in outcomes.
Extent of differences between observations.
Measure of consistency.
Range of deviation in data.
